Award.AwardTitle: CMISS: DIMACS Project on CS/Math in Service to Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The DIMACS Project on Computer Science / Mathematics in Service to Society provides a national resource for a large community of researchers and educators in computer science and related mathematical and statistical areas as well as their collaborators in fields such as biology, chemistry, physics, engineering, public health, business, and the social sciences. The project enhances and encourages programs that emphasize applications of computer science, mathematics, and statistics to problems of society involving topics such as homeland security, energy, climate change, health care, and the economy. The project also emphasizes development of fundamental methods of computer science and related areas of mathematics and statistics. This award partially supports the DIMACS Center infrastructure required to achieve project goals.

Research programs enabled by the infrastructure this project supports are organized around special focus programs consisting of workshops, research workshop groups, tutorials, and a visitor program, on topics including Computational and Mathematical Epidemiology; Algorithmic Foundations of the Internet; Hardness of Approximation; Algorithmic Decision Theory; Cybersecurity; Sharing Information; Computational Problems in Medical Informatics; Algorithms and Energy; and Dynamic Data Analysis. Educational programs similarly enabled integrate research and education across levels from precollege through postdoctoral via activities including an extensive Research Experiences for Undergraduates program; a Reconnect program run at satellite locations around the country for 2-year and 4-year college faculty highlighting recent research topics relevant to the classroom; a year-round program of workshops for middle and high school teachers; development of modular materials at the interface between the biological and mathematical sciences for use in high schools; development of high school classroom modules related to computational thinking and to data analysis and homeland security; and a program of advanced study institutes in bio-mathematics for US and African graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project – Computer Science/Mathematics in Service to Society (CMISS) – provided partial support for the DIMACS infrastructure, which is vital to the success of all DIMACS programs. Through its support of infrastructure, CMISS helped all DIMACS programs. In so doing, the project helped to promote research on fundamental methods and theory to advance computer science and related mathematics while also encouraging their application in areas motivated by the potential to address challenges facing society.

DIMACS’s signature activity is the “special focus” (SF), a multi-year program of coordinated activities addressing a broad topic, comprising such activities as workshops (WSs), research working groups (WGs), and research visitors. Each SF concentrates on an area that is poised for rapid advancement, has a high potential for impact in CSM, other areas of science, industry, or society and is likely to spawn continuing collaborations and lasting research activities. The eight DIMACS SFs underway during the CMISS project reflected its aim to strengthen the role of computer science and mathematics in the service of society. They were: 1) Computational and Mathematical Epidemiology; 2)  Information Processing in Biology; 3)  Algorithmic Foundations of the Internet; 4) Hardness of Approximation 5) Algorithmic Decision Theory; 6) Cybersecurity; 7) Information Sharing and Dynamic Data Analysis; and 8) Algorithms and Energy. Each of these areas has compelling research challenges and many also have strong potential benefits to society. These SFs involved (and ongoing ones continue to involve) a large number of people from various scientific communities.

In addition to the special foci, DIMACS is leading an effort to continue activities related to “Mathematics of Planet Earth” (MPE) beyond 2013, and it plays an ever-expanding role in homeland security through the Command, Control and Interoperability Center for Advanced Data Analysis (CCICADA), a DHS Center of Excellence based at DIMACS. CCICADA coordinates the efforts of 11 university and 5 industry partners. It jointly sponsors events and enables us to sustain our popular Reconnect program, involve more graduate students in DIMACS projects, provide fellowships to graduate students, and expand our REU program. CCICADA research projects conducted at DIMACS have led to transition of tools to the US Coast Guard for allocating boats and aircrafts missions, as well as collaboration with all major sports leagues on safety and security screening practices.

During the CMISS project, DIMACS held over 80 workshops, working groups, or other research conferences, including the 2011 workshop on Algorithms in the Field, two workshops for Aspiring PIs in Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace, and four “Reconnect” workshops. DIMACS also hosted the 2013 CISE REU PIs meeting and served as local host for the 2012 IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS). We estimate that there were roughly 3000 participants at DIMACS workshops and related events during the CMISS project.

DIMACS has been a pioneer in integrating research and education, engaging diverse participants at all education levels, from K-12 to postdoctoral. Our SF events typically include tutorials, funding for non-local graduate students to participate in WSs and WGs, and coordination with DIMACS’s outreach and educational activities.
